prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our observations are in the spectral continuum mode -- we intend to average the full 7.5GHz bandwidth.
The targets are expected to be unresolved on these scales. The requested angular resolution is such as to match the IRAC images.

The requested RMS is required to achieve detections under the assumption that the SPIRE flux is resolved into multiple components. The SPIRE detection threshold is set at 12mJy, which translates to 2-3mJy at 870um (depending on redshift within the z=3-4 range). We set 2mJy as the expected peak flux density for all targets with SPIRE detections. The RMS (0.150mJy) is such as to be able to achieve a 3sigma detections even if that flux is split among 4 sources (or more realistically 2-3 sources of unequal far-IR flux).
Our observations are in the spectral continuum mode. We intend to average the full 7.5GHz bandwidth
The targets are expected to be unresolved at the requested resolution. We request 1arcsec resolution to match the IRAC data.

For main-sequence stars, of the mass-redshift range we study here, we expect SFRs of ~100Msun/year. This translates to ~200uJy in the ALMA Band7 observations requested (see Figure2right). Our target RMS of 60uJy would result in a 3sigma detection.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA Band 7 continuum observations of 40 Mstar>10^11Msun z=3-4 galaxies. Herschel SPIRE detections are available for 15 of the targets; however, these likely suffer from source confusion. The proposed ALMA data will resolve this uncertainty and provide detections down to a SFR~100Msun/yr for the SPIRE-undetected sources. We will address three specific science goals. First, constrain the far-IR emission to derive accurate SFR and ISM masses. Second, combine the existing stellar mass estimates with the ALMA-based SFR estimates (including stacking) to provide a complete census of the mode of star-formation (quiescent, normal-mode or bursting). Thirdly, use the surrounding field in the ALMA images, to study the environments of our galaxies on a ~100kpc scales, compmlementing ongoing work based on the IRAC images. Differences between the two can highlight processes such as tidal stripping. Together, these goals will shed light on the processes governing the most massive galaxies growth at an epoch when most are still building-up their mass.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Tufts University
